name: MONKSHOOD
description: 5 showy blue to purple sepals, with the upper sepal forming the hood.
habitat: forest openings, wet meadows and thickets.

name: BANEBERRY
description: flower stalks slender.
habitat: deep shaded areas in forests.

name: SASKATOON SERVICEBERRY
description: upright, arching branches form a rounded crown; leaves broadly ovate (egg-shaped), sharply rounded at the base; flowers in axillary (where the leaf joins the stem) clusters; leaves and twigs glabrous (hairless) in age.
habitat: forested parts of mountains.

name: PINK PUSSYTOES
description: mat-forming usually with leafy stolons (stem running along surface of the ground); leaves in a basal rosette are white-tomentose on both sides (densely covered with thick-wooly hairs with no distinct orientation); phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding a composite head) pink or white.
habitat: forested areas.

name: GUNNISON MARIPOSA
description: cup-shaped flower with 3 petals and 3 sepals; petals with dark hairy spot at their base.
habitat: aspen groves, meadows on the Eastern Slope

name: COMMON FIREWEED
description: raceme (flower cluster with stalked flowers along a main axis) not leafy; styles hairy at the base, exceeding the stamens.
habitat: burned areas, roadsides, forest openings.

name: WESTERN VIRGIN'S BOWER
description: tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) 4 and thin; flowers imperfect (either male or female); styles becoming long and feathery in fruit.
habitat: valley bottoms; riparian areas at 4,000 to 7,500 feet.

name: BLUE-EYED MARY
description: small widely branched plant with  maroon color on the stems and on the underside of the leaves.
habitat: open forests, disturbed areas.

name: FIELD BINDWEED
common_name: field bindweed, creeping jenny, morning glory
description: leaves triangular-hastate (arrowhead-shaped), glabrous (hairless) or nearly so.
habitat: roadsides, cultivated fields and waste places.

name: TWINBERRY
description: flowers seated in conspicuous, leaflike cup of bracts (small leaf-like structures).
habitat: along mountain streams and moist slopes at 6,000 to 10,000 feet.

name: SULPHUR FLOWER
description: grows in broad, loose mats; perianth (petals and sepals) narrowed at the base to a stipe (stalk) and externally glabrous (smooth).
habitat: forest openings, dry meadows, rocky slopes at 5,000 to 11,500 feet.

name: REDSTEM FILAREE
description: carpel (seed pod section) tails hairy on inner side; leaves pinnately compound.
habitat: disturbed sites

name: ALPINE WALLFLOWER
description: siliques (fruits) almost glabrous (hairless) and ascending, nearly parallel to the stem although pedicels (stalks) may spread widely.
habitat: gravelly slopes and hillsides and forest openings.

name: BEDSTRAW
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped), blunt-tipped, 4 at a node (point on a stem where leaves or branches occur); inflorescence (flower cluster) pyramidal.
habitat: moist meadows and woodlands.

name: RICHARDSON GERANIUM
description: petals white with purple veins, pilose (having long, soft hairs) on the lower half; plant erect with a single or a few stems.
habitat: moist, shaded areas; aspen groves, spruce-fir forests.

name: LARGE-LEAVED AVENS
description: portion of the style provided with stalked glands; terminal leaf segment usually greatly enlarged.
habitat: moist meadows and streamsides.

name: COMMON ALUMROOT
description: stamens shorter than the sepals.
habitat: cliffs and rock outcrops.

name: ROCK SPIREA
description: flowers in terminal, many-flowered panicles (repeatedly branched flower clusters).
habitat: shaded cliff-faces, rocky slopes, hillsides, riverbottoms at 4,500 to 11,000 feet.

name: FAIRY TRUMPET
common_name: skyrocket, scarlet gilia (red form), white gilia
description: ovary with 3 locules (compartments); corolla (petals) salverform (with a long narrow tube opening into a wider cup i.e. trumpet-shaped).
habitat: gravelly open areas.

name: CREEPING HOLLYGRAPE
common_name: Oregon grape, holly-grape, creeping oregon grape
description: above-ground stem short or lacking; leaflets broad with a few spiny teeth.
habitat: uplands and open coniferous forests.

name: FALSE SOLOMON SEAL
common_name: claspleaf solomon's plume, many-flowered false solomon seal
description: leaves clasping and broadly oval; flowers numerous in a dense panicle (branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: streamsides, moist meadows and gulches.

name: WILD LILY-OF-THE-VALLEY
common_name: star solomon's seal; star solomon's plume, few-flowered false solomon seal
description: flowers in a raceme (stalked flowers along a main axis).
habitat: shady, moist areas in the forested mountains.

name: CHEESEWEED
description: flower pedicels (stalks) longer than the calyx (ring of sepals); plants procumbent (trailing on the ground).
habitat: gardens, lawns, cultivated areas, waste places.

name: BLACK MEDIC
description: plants decumbent (lying flat on the ground except for the ascending tips of the branches); leaves trifoliolate (having 3 leaflets).
habitat: disturbed areas, lawns, gardens, meadows.

name: CHIMING BELLS
description: leaves glabrous (hairless), sometimes with papillae (tiny wart-like structures) above.
habitat: streamsides, near springs, ponds and other very moist areas.

name: SCORPIONWEED
description: leaves entire (without indentations); flowers in cymes (opposite branched flower clusters); cyme helicoid (coiled like a snail); stamens exserted.
habitat: open or disturbed ground of the lower mountains.

name: ASPEN
description: tree with smooth greenish or whitish bark; leaves quake in breeze due to flattened petiole (leaf stem).
habitat: moist slopes, streamsides, burned areas at 5,000 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: GAMBEL OAK
description: leaves usually over 2 inches long, not rigid.
habitat: foothills, Jefferson County and south at 5,000 to 9,000 feet elevation.

name: WOODS ROSE
description: leaflets 5 - 7; flowering stems with broad-based thorns, occasional bristles; sepals 2 mm wide at base.
habitat: valleys, gulches, trailsides at 6,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: WILD RED RASPBERRY
description: stems with prickles; leaves glaucous (contains white waxy covering) underneath.
habitat: moist forests and slopes.

name: WILD GOLDEN GLOW
description: stems over 3 ft. tall; ray flowers drooping; disk cone-shaped and greenish.
habitat: streamsides and moist areas.

name: FIGWORT
description: square stem.
habitat: disturbed areas such as fencerows, ravines, roadside ditches and around buildings.

name: RED OSIER DOGWOOD
description: branches red; leaves opposite.
habitat: shaded canyons at 4,500 to 10,000 feet.

name: FENDLER MEADOWRUE
description: flowers mostly unisexual (either male or female); anthers much longer than wide; upper and lower edges of fruits mostly convex.
habitat: meadows, aspen groves from 5,000 to 9,500 feet elevation.

name: YELLOW SALSIFY
description: flowers shorter than the phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below a composite flower head); peduncles (stalk of a flower cluster) swollen in fruit.
habitat: dry, hot valleys.

name: MULLEIN
description: leaves decurrent (base of leaves continue down the stem beyond the point of attachment); foliage woolly-pubescent (covered in dense hair-like wool).
habitat: disturbed areas, roadsides, burned areas.
